p: Within plague foci, the timing of epizootics is often predicted based on temperature and precipitation [15]. Why weather and climate are often predictive of the temporal and spatial distributions of Y. pestis, respectively, is poorly understood. Temperature and precipitation may affect the distribution and abundance of key hosts and vectors involved in Y. pestis transmission [16], [17], [18], [19], [20]. Alternatively, host and flea communities could remain stable and instead temperature could regulate the ability of Y. pestis to persist in, or be transmitted by, fleas.
